title: Lesson Three
originalHtml:
In the third lesson, students take part in a jigsaw activity that teaches them how to mine texts for information independently across a range of source perspectives.

As a final reminder, you are invited to reflect on this lesson based on your individual plans and teaching context.

For those that have taught or are currently teaching the lesson sequence, notice how your students engage with the lesson.

  • How did your students respond to the lesson?

  • What was most helpful for your students? What was challenging?

For those that are planning to teach the lesson sequence later this year, consider trying out the activities yourself and, based on your experience, reflect on how you imagine your students will engage with the lesson.

  • How do you think your students will respond to the lesson?

  • What do you imagine will be most helpful to them? What might be challenging?

Reflect and Share

Join the Lesson Three discussion to reflect:

  • If you are teaching the lesson sequence now or have already taught it, how did the jigsaw activity go with students? How did you prepare, and were those preparations helpful? Is there anything you would change next time you set up a jigsaw like this? Based on the completed note-catchers, do you think your students are ready to complete the planning sheet for the next lesson? If possible, share a couple of completed note-catchers from your students.

  • If you are teaching the lesson sequence later this year, read and annotate a few texts and try out the jigsaw note-catcher yourself. Share what that process is like for you and the implications for taking students or teachers through the process.
